comment.author: 69673880@N02
comment._content: Captain Bowen's Military Cross was gazetted on 18th July 1917. The citation says that "He led his men with great skill and courage. On four separate occasions he advanced his company and had to dig in on new lines. His personal example was of the utmost value to his men under very trying conditions." He was Lt. (acting Cpt.) at that time.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: From www.ancestry.com Born 1895 in Brentford, Middlesex to Winifred Mary and John Cuthbert Grenside Bowen. 1901Census living in Kent. National probate Calendar info: Probate: 8 Mar 1919 Death Date: 2 Sep 1918 Death Place: Hampshire, England Registry: London, England From the Great War Forum 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=36361: He was at Charterhouse, after St Cyprian's prep school. Captain Geoffrey Grenside Bowen, MC 2nd battalion Lancashire Fusiliers. Landed in France in Sept. 1914, killed in action 2 Sept. 1918. His family collected his photographs into a bound album and published his letters and diaries in a privately printed book. His death and funeral are described in a letter written to Capt. Bowen's father by his servant Pte Jack Davidson, MM . He was from Chislehurst (Kent) and his name (misspelled Bowan) appears on the village memorial of those who fell in the Great War.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content:
Charterhouse School Roll of Honour details
Geoffrey Grenside Bowen Captain. Born 8th August 1895, 1st son of Mr. J. C. G. and Mrs. W. M. Bowen, of Durmast Cottage, Burley, Brockenhurst, Hants. He was at Charterhouse [g] 1909 - 1913. He was commissioned into the Lancashire Fusiliers and joined 2nd Bn. He was twice wounded. He was mentioned in despatches and awarded the M.C. He was killed in action on 2nd September 1918. His grave is at Windmill British Cemetery, Monchy-le-Preux, Ref. II. D. 18.  (This is 7km SE of Arras, France.)

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: He has a stone tablet memorial - in St John the Baptist Church, Burley, Hampshire with inscription: IN MEMORY OF/ CAPT. G.G. BOWEN M.C./ 2ND LANCS. FUS. KILLED/ AT EVERPIGNY, FRANCE/ 2ND SEPTEMBER 1918/ IN THE FINAL/ VICTORIOUS ADVANCE/ AGED 23 YEARS www.ukniwm.org.uk/server/show/conMemorial.21411/fromUkniw... (I think this would be Eterpigny, Somme - there is no Everpigny.) His parents lived in Burley. It would appear his medals and personal effects were sold on eBay 1914-1918.invisionzone.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=83818
